A Robot Is Unraveling the Secrets of How Some Bats Bounce Sound Waves Off Leaves to Find Insect Prey
A new study from the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute used a robot to mimic common big-eared bats’ echolocation skills
Common big-eared bats are remarkable hunters. In 2019, bat ecologist Inga Geipel and her colleagues reported that the roughly two-inch-long creatures seem to use leaves like “acoustic mirrors” to echolocate silent, motionless insect prey.
“Think of shining a light at an oblique angle or a steep angle at the mirror,” says Geipel, of the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama. “You don’t get the light reflected back to you.” But it could bounce off another object—like a dragonfly resting on a leaf—which reflects the light back into your face.
“That’s what the bats do,” she says.
But how could a bat possibly know the position and orientation of every nearby leaf to situate itself at the best listening spot? New research involving a robot has demonstrated a potential, more efficient foraging technique: As a bat travels—making rapid clicking sounds along the way—the leaf angles change relative to the creature, and it can discriminate the weak echo of an empty leaf from the stronger echo of one holding prey.
Geipel and some colleagues involved in the previous study describe their new findings on January 14 in the Journal of Experimental Biology.
Did you know? A big, broad diet
Common big-eared bats eat a wide range of prey, including beetles, caterpillars, spiders and even lizards. They eat relatively large creatures that are sometimes even the same size as the small bats.
Back in 2019, the “acoustic mirror” discovery raised new questions for the researchers. For instance, figuring out the locations and angles of all surrounding leaves would require a lot of the bats’ brain power and energy, Geipel says.
To figure out a simpler and more likely hunting strategy, the team built a robot and had it echolocate a 3D-printed dragonfly positioned on one of five artificial leaves. The machine was programmed to continuously emit ultrasonic calls—too high-pitched for humans to hear—and assess changes in echo strength as it traveled along a nearly ten-foot-long track. Weak or diminishing echoes led the robot to lose interest, while consistently strengthening echoes from different positions caused it to reorient toward the source, indicating potential prey.
When tested in 150 trials with various leaf tilt angles, the robot successfully detected the location of the fake dragonfly 98 percent of the time.
The study suggests that common big-eared bats should be “able to perceive the echolocation glints across a really wide range of angles, so they can fly in front of the cluttered background,” says Teague O’Mara, a behavioral ecologist and director of conservation evidence at Bat Conservation International who was not involved in the study.
“It’s not so important what angles that the leaves are sitting at. For them, it is that they’re still going to be able to pick up that really faint echolocation signal coming back to the bats to find that prey,” he adds.
Geipel says using a robot to model bat foraging behaviors allows for precise control over various factors, such as sensory inputs and environmental conditions. This helps researchers like her explore how simple echolocation tools could support the sophisticated navigation and prey detection system that bats use.
“I think this study gives us a good base to go back to look at the behavior in a more generalized way and see if this could be the underlying strategy for all gleaning bats to find the location of food in a more detailed and precise way,” Geipel says.
While more research is needed, she hopes that insights from how bats scan leaves for prey could inspire new agricultural technologies. She envisions robots moving through crop fields to detect and target pest insects, reducing the need for broad pesticide use, and automated systems that identify and harvest ripe fruit.

This Plant Produces Plump, Fake Berries to Trick Birds Into Spreading Its Offspring Far and Wide
The black-bulb yam excels at mimicry, producing small clones of itself that look like the dark, shiny berries of seed-growing plants
Ecological biologist Gao Chen was out collecting seeds in China in 2019 when he stumbled upon a vine that appeared to be loaded with luscious berries. But when Chen and his colleagues at the Chinese Academy of Sciences took a closer look, they realized the tasty-looking orbs weren’t berries at all—but, rather, a savvy trick the plant had evolved to ensure its survival.
The black-bulb yam seems to grow fake berries in hopes of attracting birds that will help spread its cloned offspring far and wide, the team reports in a paper published January 12 in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
Found in South and Southeast Asia, among other places, the black-bulb yam is an edible wild relative of cultivated yams. This climbing vine produces nutrient-rich tubers as well as small, detachable buds called bulbils. People sometimes use the buds to make wine or porridge, but for the plant, these bulbils are essential for reproduction.
Many plants reproduce sexually, meaning pollen gets transferred from one plant to another to produce seeds. But some species—including the black-bulb yam—have lost the ability to reproduce sexually at some point in their evolutionary histories. Instead, they reproduce asexually by making genetically identical versions of themselves. Black-bulb yams produce these clones as bulbils.
In other bulbil-producing species, the clones typically drop to the ground and take root close to the parent plant. This arrangement is less than ideal, since it means both new and old plants must compete for limited resources. But the black-bulb yam appears to have figured out a way around this issue.
The plant has adapted to produce dark, shiny, attractive-looking clones that could easily be mistaken for berries. Its bulbils are not actually fruit, but that doesn’t stop some birds from gulping them down and dispersing them via their droppings.
The birds don’t reap any nutritional benefits from this interaction. But the berry-like clones of the black-bulb yam get to hitch free rides to new spots that are farther away from their parent plants, which may give them better chances of survival. “It’s a clever evolutionary workaround,” says Kenji Suetsugu, an evolutionary ecologist at Kobe University in Japan who was not involved with the research, to Science News’ Elizabeth Pennisi.
Fun fact: Other clever plant tricks
Beyond bulbils and seeds, plants have also evolved other sneaky ways to attract pollinators and ward off enemies. Corpse flowers lure beetles and flies by mimicking the aromas of rotting flesh, for instance, while a group of plants known as cycads attract beetles by producing heat.
After their revelation in 2019, Chen and his colleagues decided to formally investigate the black-bulb yam’s deceptive tactics. They gathered the plant’s bulbils, then compared their size and color to actual berries produced by 27 other species growing nearby. Examining the colors and details that birds can see revealed that to these animals, the bulbils are nearly indistinguishable from berries.
The researchers also set up cameras near 27 black-bulb yam plants, then spent about three years recording to learn which birds seemed to be fooled into eating the bulbils. Though lots of birds visited the plants, they often left the berry-like clones alone. But when other berries were scarce, some birds did chow down on the bulbils.
In total, the team recorded 22 species of birds munching on the plant parts. One of the most common was the brown-breasted bulbul, a small, common songbird in the region. The bulbils passed through the birds’ digestive systems relatively quickly—within about 30 minutes, on average—and were excreted largely intact and viable. Based on the team’s calculations, the birds could be transporting the bulbils nearly half a mile away, in some instances, before pooping them out.
The black-bulb yam is far from the only organism to use deceptive tactics to its benefit. Dozens of plants produce what are known as “mimetic seeds,” also known as “imitative seeds,” which are seeds that appear to be wrapped in delicious, juicy, brightly colored, fruit-like coatings but actually provide very little nutrition to birds. These plants mostly grow in the tropics and include species like the marble berry and the common peony.
And some plants trick animals into doing their bidding by mimicking other items, such as silver arrowreed, a grass that produces seeds that look and smell like antelope droppings. Dung beetles roll the poop-like seeds and bury them.
“There has been a lot of chemical evolution going on to get the beetles to do the job,” Jeremy Midgely, an evolutionary ecologist at the University of Cape Town in South Africa and co-author of the study describing the plant’s strategy, told New Scientist's Sam Wong in 2015. “I’m hoping this is one of the best, if not the best, example of deception in seed dispersal.”

A Sprawling Sculpture Garden Featuring Modern Masterpieces Is Coming to the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam
The new space will feature artworks by the likes of Alberto Giacometti, Louise Bourgeois and Alexander Calder. Officials say it will be free for anyone to visit
The Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam has announced plans to install a new permanent sculpture garden. Funded by a $70 million donation from the Don Quixote Foundation, the museum’s largest private benefactor, the new garden, situated “just a stone’s throw” from the Rijksmuseum, will merge three existing pavilions and their connected gardens into a single sculpture garden, according to a statement.
“This is a wonderful gift for everyone in Amsterdam,” says Femke Halsema, Amsterdam’s mayor, in the statement, adding that people will soon be “enjoying the tranquil natural surroundings and artistic beauty.”
The garden is expected to cost around $11.6 million, as DutchNews reports. The rest of the donation from the foundation, which was created by billionaire Rolly van Rappard, will go to other museum activities.
The British architectural firm Foster + Partners will turn the pavilions into new exhibition spaces, and Belgian landscape architect Piet Blanckaert will design the garden. Foster + Partners is best known for its work in London, including projects such as Wembley Stadium and the Millennium Bridge. Blanckaert is a landscape architect and the author of Gardens, a book showcasing a large selection of his designs from the Baltic to the Mediterranean.
The sculpture garden will showcase an array of modern art, housing pieces by world-renowned artists such as Alberto Giacometti, Louise Bourgeois and Alexander Calder. Works on view will include both long-term loans from the Don Quixote Foundation and works from the museum’s own collection, which includes more than one million objects.
Quick fact: What is Alexander Calder known for?
Born in 1898, the American artist is famous for his colorful kinetic sculptures and mobiles.
In the statement, Taco Dibbits, general director of the Rijksmuseum, calls the announcement a “historic moment” for the museum, giving modern sculpture the “visibility it deserves” and marking an “unprecedented enhancement of the Rijksmuseum’s collection of 20th-century art.”
In addition to the sculptures on display, there will also be space for 22 new mature trees and a variety of native flowers and plants, increasing the city’s biodiversity.
“As far as I’m concerned, they can do it tomorrow,” Ans Lievense, who has lived in the area for four decades, tells the Art Newspaper’s Senay Boztas. “I’m for nature, and there will be so many new trees that it will be terrific.”
The Rijksmuseum is one of Europe’s most-visited art institutions, attracting nearly 2.5 million visitors in 2024. It is home to some of art history’s most famous paintings, including Johannes Vermeer’s The Milkmaid and Rembrandt’s The Night Watch.
The new sculpture garden isn’t the only planned expansion at the museum. In December, officials announced that they plan to open a new branch in the southern Dutch city of Eindhoven in an effort to increase public access to its collection, “only a fraction of which is now on view,” per Artnet’s Jo Lawson-Tancred.
Visitors will be able to access the new garden free of charge, with exact opening hours yet to be announced. The permit application has been submitted, and the museum currently plans to open the new space in the fall of 2026.

articles.content:
Oscar Wilde’s Portraits, Poems, Letters and Manuscripts Head to Auction 125 Years After His Death
Other rare items, available for purchase in February, include illustrations, theater programs, telegrams and newspapers
A collection of more than 150 poems, letters, manuscripts and signed books once belonging to Oscar Wilde—the Irish writer celebrated for his sharp wit—is heading to the auction block this February, just a few months after the 125th anniversary of his death.
Highlights of the sale include rare portraits of the young writer, captured in photographer Napoleon Sarony’s New York studio shortly after Wilde arrived in America for the first time in 1882. The 27-year-old is outfitted in a velvet jacket, silk stockings and patent leather shoes. When they started circulating, Sarony’s images “cast Wilde in the public imagination as a sartorial icon radiating charisma and intelligence,” as Artnet’s Min Chen writes.
It would be a few years before the writer who set the studio aflame that day would publish the works for which he is now well-known, including The Picture of Dorian Gray (1890), The Importance of Being Earnest (1895) and De Profundis, which he wrote while imprisoned for his homosexuality between 1895 and 1897.
Quick fact: How Oscar Wilde wrote De Profundis
The author wasn’t allowed to write plays, essays or novels while in prison—but he was permitted to write letters, and “the regulations did not specify how long a letter should be,” according to the Guardian’s Colm Tóibín. “If a letter were not finished, then the prisoner, it was supposed, could be allowed [to] take it with him when he left the prison.”Presented by the auction house Bonhams in London on February 18, the lots come from the collection of Jeremy Mason, who has been accumulating Wilde memorabilia since he purchased a first-edition copy of The Importance of Being Earnest that once belonged to the actor Ernest Thesiger many years ago.
“The collection just grew from there and now contains books, letters and manuscripts from each period of Wilde’s life from childhood, school years, America, his fame as an author, the theater ‘golden years’ and the tragedy and exile,” Mason says in a statement. “Most importantly, the collection has been enhanced by the inclusion of evocative items of ephemera which have added color to the Wilde story and were so important to me when deciding which other items to add.”
Some of these items include trade cards and illustrations advertising Wilde’s tour of North America in 1882, as well as reviews and articles Wilde wrote for various magazines. Other lots feature sheet music and theater programs from performances of Wilde’s plays.
A first-edition copy of Wilde’s French-language play Salome (1893), inscribed to Stuart Merrill, a writer and friend who helped Wilde with his French, is expected to be the biggest-ticket item, with an estimate of $20,000 to $33,000. Merrill organized a petition calling for Wilde’s clemency after he was jailed, and the lot includes two of his letters that comment on the case.
During his imprisonment in England, Wilde wrote De Profundis, a 50,000-word manuscript addressed to Lord Alfred Douglas, whom Wilde affectionately called “Bosie.” Considered by some to be the greatest love letter ever written, it remains a celebrated work to this day. This March, the Museum of Literature Ireland will stage an adaptation of the work.
In 2016, an iron key to Wilde’s jail cell was sold at a Sotheby’s auction. The key was once used to open all the doors in the prison’s cell block C, including Wilde’s.
“The heavy dark Victorian key does speak quite loudly and poignantly of the contrast between the freedom and lightness of Oscar Wilde’s wit and that terrible time in his life,” Gabriel Heaton, an expert in English literature at Sotheby’s, told the Guardian’s Maev Kennedy ahead of the sale.
